desc: We have several species of onions in the canyon. These are two of the most common. Smells and tastes “oniony.” Edible.

A smooth-stemmed, 1-4’ tall shrub. Leaves absent in winter. Whitish-green flowers; greenish-yellow berries. Very common, especially along waterways. Can cause mild to very severe itching and/or blistering. If you only learn one Hells Canyon plant, learn this one well and avoid it!

This very small plant blooms in early spring and grows 3-5” tall. Its roots were dug by the Nez Perce, dried and pounded to a flour, and used to make a food that early white settlers thought looked like biscuits.
This large biscuitroot has finely-dissected, gray-green leaves.
Blooms in early summer in dry, open areas. Roots used by Nez Perce for food.
This host plant for monarch caterpillars blooms in summer. Milky sap.
This 15-24” tall camas especially likes the rocky hillsides along the Hells Canyon scenic byway drive.
This much-smaller cousin of Cusick’s camas grows only 10-12” tall in wet meadows. It was one of the primary roots gathered for food by the Nez Perce.
Distinctive ball-shaped flower cluster at the top of a single, leafless stem. 12-20” tall.
Blooms in summer. Used medicinally by the Nez Perce and by settlers.
Spring-summer bloom. Note the very jagged leaves. Hybridizes with d. sagittata. Seeds used as food by Nez Perce.

note: see also Hoary Balsamroot; check with Rob about hybridization
desc: Spring-summer bloom. Hybridizes with d. hookeri. [?] Leaves have smooth margins. Seeds used as food by Nez Perce.

note: Should this be Diffuse instead of Spotted? or...?
desc: Common invasive biennial weed. There are many similarly-looking species.
Distinctive gray-green foliage.
Fairly common invasive biennial thistle. Can grow up to 4’ tall.
Blooms late-summer to fall. Previously known as Chrysothamnos nauseosa. A common shrub, 2-4’ tall.
A huge and variable genus; this is one of many species found in Hells Canyon.
Spring-summer bloom. Ray-flowers are orangish towards central disc, paler yellow on ends.
Yellow ray flowers may be reddish towards central disc.
Base of flower very sticky with sap.
Pale yellow bloom.
Another of many sunflower look-alikes.
Flower heads face the sun throughout the day. Grows up to 5’ tall.
Late-summer bloom

note: Not sure if invasive or native. Also not sure of the latin name: is this Matricaria matricarioides?
desc: Usuaully low-growing in disturbed areas. Plant smells like pineapple when crushed.
Told from true dandelion by its long, skinny leaves.
Toxic to livestock.
Yellow bloom; looks like a giant dandelion when gone to seed. Also called Oysterplant, as its root supposedly tastes like oysters.
Somewhat evergreen; many leaves retained through winter. Yellow flowers and berries.
Flowers inconspicuous and coiled like a scorpion’s tail.
Highly invasive weed, especially in moist areas. Flower is deep blue.

Invasive biennial weed. First year plant is a rosette of foliage with no bloom. Second year plant sends up a blooming stalk with purple-red flowers that bees love. Flowers ripen into velcro-like stickers. If you don’t find this one, your dog will!
Blooms in late spring to early summer. Very blue, tubular flowers.
This very large genus includes both native and non-native plants ranging in height from 2-15”. Many are small and not showy.
Yellow, sweet-smelling blooms appear in late spring and early summer.
A rare cactus in Hells Canyon uplands. Very compact and low to the ground.
The common cactus in Hells Canyon. Yellow flowers and long, sharp spines.
Distinctive green-stemmed shrub with tiny leaves. Stands 1-3’ tall.

note: Double check ID with Rob. Is it Cerastium? Eremogone? Moehringia? Sabulina?
desc: Fairly conspicuous white flowers.
Short, cushiony clump of tiny white blooms. Likes dry, gravelly soil.

note: Lychis or Silene? Check species. Also should it be “non-native” or “invasive”?
desc: Showy white blossoms. Plant is 1-2’ tall.
Vining perennial invasive weed.
Common in rocky, dry sites. Can also be found among rocks in mountains.
This photo shows both teasel and flannel mullein. Teasel is the tall plant to the right of center. It blooms purple and the head ripens to a spiny brown seedhead at the end of the stem.
Very invasive weed with yellow-green flowers and milky sap. Toxic to livestock.
The palmately compound leaves help identify these plants, which consist of many different species in any different habitats.
Flower heads are golf-ball sized and 6-8” tall.
Can be confused with common camas, but each flower has only four petals rather than six, and the leaf edges are whitish.
Biennial that forms a rosette of long, strap-like leaves in its first year; sends up a 2-5’ tall spike of unique whitish-green flowers in its second year.
Usually 3-4” tall with tiny pink flowers and lobed leaves. Flower matures into a long, pointed seed capsule which resembles a stork’s bill to some.
Very showy, early-summer bloomer in grasslands and open forests.
A sweet-smelling shrub that blooms in late spring in the canyon. Another of our plants named for Captain Meriweather Lewis.
Ball-shaped flower cluster is often hidden below leaves.
Short-lived Oregon native perennial, so-named because the flower spike is curled like a scorpion’s tail.
Light purplish-blue blossoms on a 6-10” tall plant.
Invasive weed. Hold leaves up to light and see the tiny “perforations,” actually lighter green markings, on leaves.
Early-blooming, magenta-pink. 5-8” tall. Often covers the ground with many plants together.
“Mariposa” means “butterfly” in Spanish. These members of the Lily family not only resemble butterflies, but are also attractive nectar sources for them.
One of the earliest spring blooms. 3-6” tall. Forms a round white seed pod.
A showy yet delicate bloom on the end of a 15-24” stem. Leaves are very small.
Although the blooms are completely different than those of Common Camas, the roots are very similar in looks but are toxic. Definitely not used as food.
This mint-family member grows in vigorous clumps and is very popular with insect pollinators. Up to 3’ tall.
As its name implies, this plant blooms in spring. All parts are edible.
A semi-succulent plant named after Meriweather Lewis of the Lewis and Clark expedition. Only found in dry, rocky sites.
A very distinctive, round-leaved perennial known from only a few upland sites in Hells Canyon. Named after an early Snake River boatman.
This plant was one of many that were collected by Lewis and Clark, and named accordingly.
One of more than a dozen species of orchids in northeast Oregon, this one is found along moist springs in Hells Canyon.
We have many varieties of paintbrush, in colors ranging from pale yellow to orangeish-red to scarlet. All are partially parasitic plants, often associated with sagebrush.
This weirdly-named plant is usually found growing singly. It is 3-5” tall and parasitic on other plants, because it has no chlorophyll to manufacture its own food.
The taxonomy of this plant is confusing and often being revised. It is a close relative of Indian Paintbrush. Formerly in family Scrophulariaceae. Also called Castilleja tenuifolius.
The unique brownish bloom and much-lobed, gray-green leaves identify this plant. Not nearly as showy as garden-variety peonies.
Unmistakable blooms on long, drooping stems. Always in moist areas.
This is our only deciduous conifer; that is, its needles turn gold in the fall and drop off. The needles are short, 1-2” long in bundles of 10-15.

note: trunk bark, coniferous tree; long needles in groups of 3
desc: Needles on this conifer are 5-6” long and borne in groups of three. Thick bark of mature trees is fire-resistant. Snags of Larch and Ponderosa Pine are used as nest sites for many birds and mammals.
A short-needled conifer with distinctive cones (note the bracts extending beneath each cone scale). This and Ponderosa pine are the common conifers of Hells Canyon. Needles found singly on twigs.
A tiny spring-blooming plant that seldom exceeds 4” in height.
As its name implies, this white penstemon prefers hot, dry, rocky sites.
A very showy semi-shrub, often seen on rocky cliffs.
Another large genus, most of ours are blue, purple, or white, and all have showy spikes of summer-blooming flowers.  Formerly in the Scrophulariaceae family.
Hummingbirds love this flower, which comes in shades from light pink to scarlet.
A common spring bloom in the grasslands and along the Snake River.
Blooms in summer. Flowers are in groups called umbels at the ends of 12-15” stems. Foliage is grayish green and mostly basal.
Thyme-leaved buckwheat and creamy buckwheat form semi-shrubby mats 8-15” tall on dry slopes.
This plant is a good source of Vitamin C.
An early-spring bloomer. Leafless stem above a basal rosette of leaves.
Many of the members of the buttercup family look nothing like a typical “buttercup.” This is a good example.
This native plant is toxic to cattle if eaten in quantity. We have several common species.
This is one of the first flowers to show up in spring. It is often hidden in the brown grass of winter.
The first shrub to bloom in spring. Its fruits are dark blue, small and seedy, but good to eat.
A shrub that often forms dense thickets. Foliage turns red in fall. Long, straight thorns on stems.
Very common on grassy slopes and meadows. The name comes from the way extensive patches look when in seed.
This shrub is found in partial shade, in pine or Douglas-fir stands. It blooms in mid-summer.
This low-growing shrub was used by the Nez Perce for its fiber in basket-making. It turns red in the fall.

This large genus is well-represented in Hells Canyon. Besides several native species, there is a non-native, invasive variety, Potentilla recta (Sulfur Cinquefoil) that has very hairy stems and very pale yellow flowers.
A tall shrub, usually found close to waterways. Clusters of bright red berries in seed. Birds and bears love them. This was an important food plant for the Nez Perce.
Rose hips, the fruit of this plant, are high in Vitamin C. We have several native species as well as non-native invasives.
This native does not form big thickets as blackberries do. The berries are delicious.
Large, fast-growing broadleaf tree found along streams.
This plant’s root was used medicinally by the Nez Perce and by settlers.
This delicate little plant’s genus is derived from the Latin for “rock breaker.” Apparently it is tougher than it looks. It grows 4-6” tall.
An invasive weed resembling garden snapdragons, may be harmful to livestock.
The fuzzy, thick leaves of this yellow-flowered plant are distinctive. It grows 4-6’ tall. The photo on the right shows both Mullein (left) and Teasel (right).
This invasive plant is covered with tiny hairs that irritate skin. Young plants can be carefully gathered and boiled for a spring green.
This small purple bloom has a distinct spur visible behind the main petals.
A yellow version of the common purple-petaled violet.
Lichens are plants composed of both an algae and a fungus. They are tiny (less than an inch tall) and found growing on rocks and tree bark.
